article.title: Single-electron thermal devices coupled to a mesoscopic gate

choices: A quantum dot system coupled to a mesoscopic gate, showing energy-dependent tunneling rates.
A schematic of a traditional transistor, highlighting the emitter, base, and collector.
A representation of electron-electron interactions in a single quantum dot system.
A graph of heat flow as a function of temperature in a simple two-terminal conductor.

multiple_choice_question.text: What is the main takeaway from Figure 2?
choices: Heat current in the gate dot is constant regardless of gate voltages.
Heat currents in the conductor exhibit a double peak structure, influenced by the gate dot\'s charging state.
Temperature gradients applied to the conductor terminals have no impact on the gate dot.
Heat flow in this system consistently violates the Clausius statement of the second law.

multiple_choice_question.text: What does Figure 3 illustrate about the system?
choices: Increasing the gate temperature has a negligible effect on heat currents in the conductor.
Thermal gating, evidenced by the clover-leaf structure, occurs due to fluctuations in the gate dot.
The thermal gating effect is most pronounced when the gate dot level is far from the Fermi energy.
Energy exchange between the system and the gate is maximized when fluctuations in the gate are suppressed.

multiple_choice_question.text: In Figure 4, what is the significance of the energy-selected-tunneling configuration (ΓLO = ΓRO = 0)?
choices: It enables heat injection from the gate dot into the conductor.
It leads to a suppression of heat currents in the lower region of the stability diagram.
It eliminates the thermal gating effect by preventing fluctuations in the gate dot.
It results in heat currents flowing from the gate into the conductor even without a temperature gradient.

multiple_choice_question.text: What unique phenomenon does Figure 7 demonstrate?
choices: The possibility of achieving thermal gating without any energy cost by manipulating gate barriers.
The breakdown of the Clausius statement, with heat flowing from cold to hot reservoirs.
The ability to cool one conductor terminal by heating the opposite terminal through gate interactions.
The complete suppression of heat currents in the conductor by carefully tuning the gate dot potentials.
